did.unittitle: Northern Michigan Environmental Action Council records
did.abstract: The Northern Michigan Environmental Action Council is a Traverse City-based environmental watchdog group. Members are primarily from a region comprised of five counties in Northwestern Michigan including Grand Traverse, Leelanau, Benzie, Kalkaska, and Antrim counties, although some members who feel a special affinity for the region are from downstate or out of state. The papers document the council√¢??s attention to local environmental concerns and their interactions with various government agencies, corporate entities, and individuals in the name of sound environmental stewardship.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records were donated by the organization (donor no. 9740) in 2006-07.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is not held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Northern Michigan Environmental Action Council records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Northern Michigan Environmental Action Council was founded in 1980 as a response to the Big Rock Nuclear Power Plant operating near Charlevoix Michigan. Since then, the council has devoted itself to transportation management, land use, contamination cleanup, and parkland protection. The council's mission statement, "preserving the natural environment through citizen action and education", provides the master plan for their advocacy activities.

The council makes a policy of partnering with other regional and nation advocacy organizations including The Coalition for Sensible Growth (of which it is a charter member), The Anglers of the Boardman, Trout Unlimited, The Friends of the Crystal River, and the Sierra Club. Their interests have brought them into conflict with development firms, local and state governments, and corporate polluters.
The council continues to be active and more records are expected to be forthcoming.

scopecontent.p: The records of the council are divided into four series, reflecting general areas of interest to the organization: Land Use, Toxic Cleanup Efforts, Transportation, and Board Minutes. In turn, the subseries within these series reflect advocacy efforts or controversies that fall under the general category.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Cities and towns--Growth--Michigan--Grand Traverse Bay Region.
Conservation of natural resources--Michigan--Grand Traverse Bay Region.
City planning--Michigan--Grand Traverse Bay Region.
Hazardous waste sites--Michigan--Grand Traverse Bay Region.
Crystal River (Mich.)

scopecontent.p: The Land Use series includes materials documenting an effort to prevent residential development and the construction of a golf course on the Crystal River, as well as records documenting NMEAC's fight to preserve the Grand Traverse Commons (former site of the state psychiatric hospital and asylum) as public parkland. Other documents reveal the efforts to prevent the construction of Grand Traverse Mall and to prevent development of North Fox Island.

did.unittitle: Correspondence Between Robert Kuras and The Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore

Botanical Garden Society of Northwest Michigan

Michigan Department of Management and Budget
Wade-Trim, Inc., Munson Medical Center Access Study

scopecontent.p: The Toxic Cleanup Efforts series documents efforts to force corporate polluters, including Cone-Drive Textron and T.C. Light & Power, to fund cleanup efforts at sites that were contaminated as a direct result of their industrial activities.

did.unittitle: Olson, Noonan & Bzdok, Attorneys at Law
Community Decision Making in Contaminated Sediment Cleanups
Environmental Protection Agency, Cleaning Up Contaminated Sediment

scopecontent.p: The Transportation series documents NMEAC's resistance to the construction of a bridge over the Boardman River that would connect Hartman and Hammond roads. Construction of the bridge was perceived as a threat to the ecological health of the river. The motivation of the Grand Traverse Board of Road Commissioners was called into question, and a lawsuit was brought against them. The bridge also came to be understood as a stepping-stone on the path to a Traverse City bypass. In such light, many parties with differing perspectives and motivations became involved in the controversy. During this period, members of NMEAC, together with The Michigan Land Use Institute, formed The Coalition for Sensible Growth. NMEAC remains a charter member of The Coalition for Sensible Growth and the coalition's records are included in NMEAC's record group, especially within the Hartman-Hammond Bridge subseries. Recent additions to the Hartman-Hammond Bridge subseries include a large amount of public comments concerning the bridge, both pro and con. The series also includes some documents concerning the development of roundabouts in Traverse City and concern over the construction of the new BATA Transfer station.

did.unittitle: De Leuw Cather & Company of Michigan, Consultants
Grand Traverse County Board of Commissioners
Grand Traverse County Natural Education Reserve and Surroundings
Northwest Michigan Resource Conservation and Development Council
Olson, Noonan & Bzdok, Attorneys at Law
Participation Guidance Document Among Plaintiffs in the Hartman-Hartman-Three Mile Lawsuit
Resolution for Michigan Transportation Economic Development Fund

scopecontent.p: The Board Minutes series consists of minutes from the board meetings of NMEAC. These minutes discuss the projects undertaken by NMEAC as well as other environmental issues they discussed. The records include handwritten minutes, typed minutes, and agendas.
